s.text: These results suggest that ALM migrations are carefully regulated by the concentration of a specific DNA binding protein that is present in the cell in only a few copies.

The AVM touch receptor neurons in EA485, a strain which showed a strong ALM migration defect, were located in the same position as the AVMs in TU2562, a strain which showed few ALM migration defects (Fig.
Strains transformed with pJC8, pJC3, and pJC4 showed strong ALM migration defects but strains transformed with plasmids pPD118.

Figure 2shows fluorescence micrographs and bar graphs of the positions of the ALMs from strain TU2562, which has an integrated mec-3gfp (equivalent to pJC8 in Figure 4), and strain EA485, which contains a high copy extrachromosomal array made from plasmid pJC4 (see Figure 4and Materials and Methods).

We reasoned that pJC4 may have caused more severe migration defects than pJC8 and pJC3 because in pJC4 the titrating sequence was closer to the promoter and was thereby more accessible to binding factors.
We do not know whether other cell migrations were affected by the titrating sequence, but no other phenotypes were observed in animals with severe ALM migration defects.
Further deletions of this region (pJC18 and pJC19) resulted in less severe migration defects.
We do not know whether other cell migrations were affected by the titrating sequence, but no other phenotypes were observed in animals with severe ALM migration defects.
This effect is referred to as RNA interference or RNAi.
Below we refer to this sequence as the titrating sequence.
4% of 199 ALMs scored had normal axonal morphology, whereas in TU2562, all of the 117 ALMs scored had normal morphology.
